API offers a declarative idiom for customizing the formatting of various types. Also, Foundation caches identical
instances, so you don’t need to pass them around your app, or risk wasting memory with duplicate formatters.

content.text: Working With User-Visible Representations of Dates and Times

inlineContent.text: When displaying a date to a user, you set the
properties of the date formatter according to your particular needs. For example, if you want to show the month, day, and year without showing the time, you would set the
. Conversely, if you want to show only the time, you would set the
. Based on the values of the
provides a representation of a specified date that is appropriate for a given locale.
If you need to define a format that cannot be achieved using the predefined styles, you can use the
to specify a localized date format from a template.

content.text: Working With Fixed Format Date Representations

inlineContent.text: In macOS 10.12 and later or iOS 10 and later, use the
class when working with ISO 8601 date representations.
When working with fixed format dates, such as RFC 3339, you set the
property to specify a format string. For most fixed formats, you should also set the

code: /* 39 minutes and 57 seconds after the 16th hour of December 19th, 1996 with an offset of -08:00 from UTC (Pacific Standard Time) */

inlineContent.text: is thread safe so long as you are using the modern behavior in a 64-bit app.
On earlier versions of the operating system, or when using the legacy formatter behavior or running in 32-bit in macOS,
is not thread safe, and you therefore must not mutate a date formatter simultaneously from multiple threads.

abstract.text: A formatter that creates string representations of quantities of time.
A formatter that converts between dates and their textual representations.
The capitalization formatting context used when formatting a date.
